newsitem.title: JAPAN: N. Korea, consortium agree terms for power plant.
newsitem.headline: N. Korea, consortium agree terms for power plant.

text.p: North Korea and an international consortium in charge of building nuclear plants in North Korea agreed on the protocols to build a light-water reactor in the Stalinist state, official media reported on Saturday.

Representatives of Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO) and experts from the North Korean side "discussed and agreed on the protocols in keeping with the international usage and special circumstances of the provision of light-water reactors," Pyongyang's Korea Central News Agency reported.
"Full conditions for starting the light-water reactor project have been created with the agreement on the protocols," said KCNA, monitored in Tokyo.

The US-led international consortium is working to provide the North with $4.5 billion in nuclear power plants and alternative energy supplies as part of a deal to end the country's suspected nuclear weapons programme.
Stephen Bosworth, head of KEDO said earlier in the month that the construction of two North Korean nuclear reactors will start within weeks.
